instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the measurement of periodic changes in COVID-19 antibody level?
Output: Fourier Transform InfraRed (FTIR) and Raman spectroscopy methods were used in the measurement of periodic changes in COVID-19 antibody level.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the measurement of periodic changes in COVID-19 antibody level?
Output: Multivariate and machine learning analyses were used in combination with FTIR and Raman spectroscopy to measure periodic changes in COVID-19 antibody levels.

instruction: What metric was chosen in the measurement of periodic changes in COVID-19 antibody level?
Output: A correlation test was chosen in the measurement of periodic changes in COVID-19 antibody level.

instruction: How were machine learning models utilized in the analysis of the spectroscopy data to differentiate antibody levels at different time points after COVID infection?
Output: Machine learning models were utilized in the analysis of the spectroscopy data to differentiate antibody levels at different time points after COVID infection. The spectroscopy data, obtained from Fourier Transform InfraRed (FTIR) and Raman spectroscopy methods, were subjected to multivariate analysis, machine learning, and neural network methods. These machine learning models were trained using the spectral biomarkers of amides II and I, which allowed for the differentiation of antibody levels between 1 and 6 months after COVID infection. Additionally, Raman spectroscopy in specific ranges of wavenumbers (1317 cm(-1) to 1432 cm(-1), 2840 cm(-1) to 2956 cm(-1)) was used to distinguish patients after 1, 3, and 6 months from COVID infection with a sensitivity close to 100%.

instruction: Can FTIR and Raman spectroscopy method be considered superior to traditional methods in differentiating antibody levels at different time points after COVID infection, based on the analysis of blood samples from infected patients?
Output: Yes, spectroscopy methods such as FTIR and Raman spectroscopy can be considered superior to traditional methods in differentiating antibody levels at different time points after COVID infection. The research mentioned in the text demonstrated that these spectroscopy methods, when combined with multivariate analysis, machine learning, and neural network methods, were able to differentiate antibody levels between 1 and 6 months after COVID infection. The use of spectral biomarkers of amides II and I in FTIR spectroscopy, as well as specific ranges of Raman spectroscopy, allowed for the accurate distinction of patients at different time points with a sensitivity close to 100%. This suggests that spectroscopy methods can provide more precise and reliable information about antibody levels compared to traditional methods.
